Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story:
I stood in the humming factory, clipboard in hand, reviewing the maintenance schedule for next week’s planned shutdown. As the lead machine repairer, everyone counted on me to ensure the machines were cleaned and serviced perfectly—any mistake could mean costly downtime. My supervisor had emphasized how critical this maintenance was, and I felt the weight of that responsibility pressing on my shoulders.

But as I walked past the break room, I overheard two coworkers talking about a shortcut—using a cleaning solvent that wasn’t approved, but would save hours of work. They planned to do it during the shutdown, and one of them winked at me, assuming I’d go along. The shortcut was against company policy and could be dangerous, but it was tempting; it would make my job easier and please my boss.

Yet, as a Christian, I knew I was called to honesty and integrity, to do what was right even when no one was watching. The thought of compromising my values gnawed at me. I felt torn between the expectations of my job and the demands of my faith, my mind swirling with anxiety as I realized I had to choose which role to honor.
